title: End-to-End Deep Learning for Structural Brain Imaging: A Unified Framework
author: Yao Su (Worcester Polytechnic Institute), Keqi Han (Emory University), Mingjie Zeng (Worcester Polytechnic Institute), Lichao Sun (Lehigh University), Liang Zhan (University of Pittsburgh), Carl Yang (Emory University), Lifang He (Lehigh University), Xiangnan Kong (Worcester Polytechnic Institute), ...
relevance_why: The unified framework for neuroimaging tasks could be adapted to audio analysis, particularly in integrating various audio processing stages into one efficient model.
background: The paper addresses the challenge of processing brain imaging data by integrating various tasks such as extraction, registration, segmentation, and classification into a single model.
contribution: This framework, named Uni-Brain, introduces an end-to-end model to simultaneously optimize multiple neuroimaging tasks, achieving improved accuracy and efficiency with minimal supervision.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods involve separate pipelines for neuroimaging tasks, requiring extensive manual intervention and leading to propagated errors between stages.
technical_comparison.novelty: Uni-Brain effectively combines these tasks into a singular optimization process, reducing the need for high-cost annotations and improving learning efficiency.

key_innovation: The model's ability to jointly configure several interdependent brain imaging tasks within a single neural network removes the bottlenecks present in traditional sequential processes.
real_world_impact: This approach could streamline brain imaging analysis in clinical settings, making it more efficient and accessible while enhancing diagnostic accuracy.
limitations: No specific limitations are mentioned in the abstract and introduction.

new_terms.parcellation: **Parcellation** refers to dividing the brain into regions for the purpose of analysis, critical for understanding functional and structural organization.
new_terms.connectome: **Connectome** is the map of neural connections in the brain, analogous to a road map detailing how different regions are interconnected.
